quizzes.question: What part of an if statement should be indented?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]if Statements[/h1]

You can use [b]if[/b] statements to run code if a certain condition holds. 
If an expression evaluates to [b]True[/b], some statements are carried out. Otherwise, they aren't carried out. 
An if statement looks like this: [code format="py"][b]if[/b] expression:
   statements[/code]
[note]Python uses [b]indentation [/b](white space at the beginning of a line) to delimit blocks of code. Other languages, such as C, use curly braces to accomplish this, but in Python indentation is mandatory; programs won't work without it. As you can see, the statements in the [b]if[/b] should be indented.[/note]

[h1]if Statements[/h1]

Here is an example [b]if[/b] statement:[code format="py" codeId="298"][b]if[/b] 10 > 5:
   print("10 greater than 5")

print("Program ended")[/code]
The expression determines whether 10 is greater than five. Since it is, the indented statement runs, and "10 greater than 5" is output. Then, the unindented statement, which is not part of the [b]if[/b] statement, is run, and "Program ended" is displayed. 

[b]Result: [/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
10 greater than 5
Program ended
>>>[/code]
Notice the [b]colon [/b]at the end of the expression in the [b]if[/b] statement.
[note]As the program contains multiple lines of code, you should create it as a separate file and run it.[/note]

[h1]if Statements[/h1]

To perform more complex checks, [b]if[/b] statements can be nested, one inside the other.
This means that the inner [b]if[/b] statement is the statement part of the outer one. This is one way to see whether multiple conditions are satisfied. 

[b]For example:[/b] [code format="py" codeId="299"]num = 12
[b]if[/b] num > 5:
   print("Bigger than 5")
   [b]if[/b] num <=47:
      print("Between 5 and 47")[/code]
[b]Result: [/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
Bigger than 5
Between 5 and 47
>>>[/code]
